"Slovenska pomlad"https://www.sds.si/o-stranki/soj
{{small|"Slovenian Spring"}}[[File:Slovenska pomlad.ogg|197px|Slovenska pomlad]] | seats1_title = [[Slovenian National Assembly|National Assembly]] | seats1 = {{composition bar|25|90|hex={{Slovenian Democratic Party/meta/color}}}} | seats2_title = [[European Parliament]] | seats2 = {{composition bar|3|8|hex={{Slovenian Democratic Party/meta/color}}}} | flag = [[File:Flag of the Slovenian Democratic Party.svg|225px|border|Flag of the Slovenian Democratic Party]] | website = {{url|sds.si}} | country = Slovenia }} The '''Slovenian Democratic Party''' ({{lang-sl|Slovenska demokratska stranka}}, SDS), formerly the '''Social Democratic Party of Slovenia''' ({{lang-sl|Socialdemokratska stranka Slovenije}}, SSS),{{Cite news|url=https://siol.net/novice/volitve-2018/slovenska-demokratska-stranka-sds-466986|title=SLOVENSKA DEMOKRATSKA STRANKA (SDS)|access-date=2018-06-04|language=sl}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.rtvslo.si/gremvolit/stranke-in-liste/sds-vec-svobode-clovekovih-pravic-in-solidarnosti/453598|title=SDS: Več svobode, človekovih pravic in solidarnosti|work=Grem Volit|access-date=2018-06-04|language=sl-SI}} is a [[Liberal conservatism|liberal-conservative]]{{cite book|author=Igor Guardiancich|title=Pension Reforms in Central, Eastern and Southeastern Europe: From Post-Socialist Transition to the Global Financial Crisis|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=APcO_fndhx0C&pg=PA194|year=2012|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-136-22595-6|page=194}}{{cite book|author=Alfio Cerami|title=Social Policy in Central and Eastern Europe: The Emergence of a New European Welfare Regime|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MJdWwGKl2iAC&pg=PA29|year=2006|publisher=LIT Verlag Münster|isbn=978-3-8258-9699-7|page=29}} [[List of political parties in Slovenia|political party]] in [[Slovenia]]. Led by [[Janez Janša]], the SDS is a member of the [[European People's Party]] (EPP),{{Cite web|url=http://www.demsoc.org/2014/05/19/slovenian-democratic-party-sds/|title=Slovenian Democratic Party (SDS) {{!}} The Democratic Society|website=www.demsoc.org|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-06-04}} [[Centrist Democrat International]]{{Cite web|url=https://idc-cdi.com/en/parties/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170922103407/https://idc-cdi.com/en/parties/|dead-url=no|archive-date=2017-09-22|title=Partidos Archivo - idc-cdi|date=2017-09-22|access-date=2018-06-04}} and [[International Democrat Union]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.idu.org/members/|title=Members {{!}} International Democrat Union|website=www.idu.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-06-04}} == History == === Origins === {{unreferenced section|date=November 2011}} The Slovenian Democratic Party has developed from the merger of two distinct political parties, being the legal successor of both of the [[Social Democratic Union of Slovenia]] and the [[Slovenian Democratic Union]], two of the most influential parties of the [[Democratic Opposition of Slovenia]]—also known as the DEMOS coalition—which defeated the former [[Communist Party of Slovenia]] in the first open Slovenian election on April 1990, and carried out the [[democratization]] of Slovenia and its [[History of Slovenia#Disintegration of Yugoslavia|secession from Yugoslavia]]. The Social Democratic Union of Slovenia had emerged from an independent, [[Anti-communism|anti-Communist]] trade union movement in the late 1980s. Its first president was the trade union leader [[France Tomšič]], who in December 1987 organized the [[Litostroj strike|first successful large-scale workers strike]] in [[Communist Slovenia]], following the example of [[Lech Wałęsa]]'s [[Solidarity (Polish trade union)|Solidarity]] movement in [[Poland]]. Tomšič however resigned soon after the founding of the party, endorsing the leadership of [[Jože Pučnik]], a former dissident who had been forced to emigrate to Germany in the 1960s. Under Pučnik's leadership, The Social Democratic Union of Slovenia gradually developed into a moderate [[social democracy|social-democratic]] party, which combined the plea for a [[social market economy]] with the support of a [[welfare state]] based on a [[German model|German]], [[Economy of Austria|Austrian]] and [[Scandinavian welfare model|Scandinavian]] social model. The Slovenian Democratic Union, on the other hand, was founded in January 1989, as opposition to the [[Communist Party of Slovenia]], emphasizing establishment of the [[rule of law]] and respect for [[human rights]] and fundamental political freedoms, respect for [[minority rights]], and the inclusion of Slovenia in the Euro-Atlantic integrations (the [[European Union]] and [[NATO]]). It functioned as a broad but somehow fragmented coalition of several groups with different [[liberalism|liberal]], [[social liberalism|social-liberal]] and [[civic nationalism|civic nationalist]] agendas. In 1992, the Slovenian Democratic Union split into two parties: the [[social liberalism|social-liberal]] wing established the [[Democratic Party (Slovenia)|Democratic Party]] (DSS), while the [[conservatism|conservative]] faction founded the [[National Democratic Party (Slovenia)|National Democratic Party]] (NDS). Members who did not join one of these two parties decided to join the Social Democratic Party led by [[Jože Pučnik]]. Although the Social Democratic Party suffered a clear defeat in the 1992 election, barely securing its entry in the [[Slovenian National Assembly|Parliament]], it formed a coalition with the winning [[Liberal Democracy of Slovenia]] (LDS) and entered the cabinet of [[Janez Drnovšek]]. In 1995, the [[National Democratic Party (Slovenia)|National Democratic Party]] joined the party, which thus became one of the legal successors of the [[Slovenian Democratic Union]].{{Citation needed|date=June 2018}} After the year 2000, the party applied for membership in the [[European People's Party]] (EPP), adopting a [[economic liberalism|liberal]] economic policy and later pro-[[austerity]] measures upon the late-2000 economic crisis, while retaining an [[atlanticism|atlantist]] foreign policy.{{Citation needed|date=June 2018}} === Radical populist turn === Upon being dismissed by Prime Minister Janez Drnovšek because of being involved in the attempts of the military interfering in civilian justice, the party's leader became [[Janez Janša]], while Jože Pučnik resigned and became the honorary president of the party (a function he held until his death in January 2003). Janša was subsequently cleared, following an inquiry. The party unconditionally supported its new leader and decided to leave the coalition and stayed in opposition for the next ten years (except for a short period in 2000, when it entered a short-lived centre-right government led by [[Andrej Bajuk]]), in the meantime gaining in popularity among – as described by one of its [[Slovenian Democratic Party#Former supporters|former supporters]], [[Peter Jambrek]] – "lower, frustrated social strata".[http://www.dnevnik.si/clanek/1042482825 Peter Jambrek o tem, da je SDS stranka frustriranih nižjih slojev], Dnevnik, 25. Cctober 2011 The party's [[Political radicalism|radical]] [[populism]], [[nationalism|nationalistic]] and [[xenophobia|xenophobic]] rhetoric was noticed also by political scientists.{{Citation |first=Rudolf M. |last=Rizman |title=Radical Right Politics in Slovenia |work=The radical right in Central and Eastern Europe since 1989 |publisher=Penn State Press |year=1999 |pages=155–162 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QZr1vsDIvlUC&printsec=frontcover&hl=de&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q=slovenian%20democratic%20party&f=false |accessdate=14 November}}{{Citation |first1=Ian |last1=Hall |first2=Magali |last2=Perrault |title=The Re-Austrianisation of Central Europe? |journal=Central Europe Review |volume=2 |number=13 |date=3 April 2000 |url=http://www.ce-review.org/00/13/essay13.html |accessdate=14 November 2011}}{{Citation |first=Rudolf M. |last=Rizman |title=Uncertain path: Democratic transition and consolidation in Slovenia |publisher=Texas A&M University Press |year=2006 |page=74 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0F5l-gI0_igC&printsec=frontcover&hl=de&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q=slovenian%20democratic%20party%20jansa&f=false |accessdate=14 November 2011}} Moreover, the local Slovenian [[Catholic Church]] supported it more than any other Slovenian political party. Even though not a nominally Christian party, the local church has stood fully and unconditionally behind it. === 2004–2008: in power (first Janša Cabinet) === On 3 October 2004, SDS won the [[Slovenian parliamentary election, 2004|2004 parliamentary election]] with 29.1% of the popular vote and 29 out of 88 seats.{{Cite web|url=http://www.dvk-rs.si/arhivi/dz2004/en/index.htm|title=Republic of Slovenia Elections for Deputies to the National Assembly 2004|website=www.dvk-rs.si|access-date=2018-06-03}} SDS then formed [[Cabinet of Janez Janša I|a coalition]] with [[New Slovenia]] (NSi), the [[Slovenian People's Party]] (SLS), and [[Democratic Party of Pensioners of Slovenia]] (DeSUS), holding a total of 49 parliamentary seats (out of 90).{{Cite news|url=http://www.rtvslo.si/volitve-v-dz/pregled-mandata-2004-2005/90806|title=Pregled mandata 2004/2005|work=Prvi interaktivni multimedijski portal, MMC RTV Slovenija|access-date=2018-06-03}} The SDS-led government passed several pro-business measures, initiated the [[regionalisation]] of the country by giving more power to local governments, and, in order to please its coalition party, DeSUS - introduced economically non-sustainable changes in the pension system.{{Citation needed|date=June 2018}} SDS has been accused of catering to the interests of the Slovenian [[Roman Catholic Church]] in exchange for political support.{{Cite news|url=https://www.mladina.si/92559/katoliska-drzava-drzavna-cerkev/|title=Katoliška država, državna cerkev {{!}} MLADINA.si|work=Mladina.si|access-date=2018-06-05}} Nevertheless, the Church maintained a critical attitude towards some of the party's positions (the SDS-led Government has assumed a favourable attitude towards [[gambling]] tourism, [[Embryonic stem cell|stem cell]] research and passed a law recognizing [[Civil unions in Slovenia|same-sex civil unions]], all opposed by the Roman Catholic Church).{{Citation needed|date=June 2018}} ==== Internal affairs ==== The government introduced measures to supervise, and to curtail the powers of the [[Slovenian Intelligence and Security Agency]]. The measures were strongly rebuked by the opposition and segments of the press as an attempt to discredit the secret intelligence service and cast a negative shadow on the policies of previous governments.{{Cite news|url=https://www.mladina.si/92630/specialna-vojna/|title=Specialna vojna {{!}} MLADINA.si|work=Mladina.si|access-date=2018-06-03}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.delo.si/novice/slovenija/komisiji-za-nadzor-sove-omejen-nadzor-v-tekocih-zadevah.html|title=Komisiji za nadzor Sove omejen nadzor v tekočih zadevah|last=Uredništvo|access-date=2018-06-03|language=sl-si}} ==== Freedom of the press violations ==== The first SDS government was the target of widespread criticism due to allegations of meddling in the independence of the press.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/04/world/europe/viktor-orban-media-slovenia.html|title=Safe in Hungary, Viktor Orban Pushes His Message Across Europe|date=2018-06-04|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-06-05|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} The first SDS government has been accused of politicising the independent press by appointing political allies{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/europe-populists-right-wing-success-marine-le-pen-viktor-orban-italy-slovenia-a8382766.html|title=The right-wing populists doing well across Europe, from Marine Le Pen to Viktor Orban|work=The Independent|access-date=2018-06-08|language=en-GB}} to leadership and journalist positioned in the state [[Slovenian Press Agency]], daily newspaper [[Delo]],{{Cite news|url=https://www.mladina.si/?__rewriter=1&id=108659&|title=J. J.? Ne, hvala! {{!}} MLADINA.si|work=Mladina.si|access-date=2018-06-03}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.dnevnik.si/1042713981/slovenija/jansev-medijski-projekt-kot-zadnje-volilno-upanje-sds|title=Janšev medijski projekt kot zadnje volilno upanje SDS|work=Dnevnik|access-date=2018-06-03}} regional newspaper [[Primorske novice]], and public media and broadcasting organisation, [[Radiotelevizija Slovenija|RTV Slovenia]]. State-owned companies also ceased purchasing adverts in the daily newspaper [[Dnevnik (Slovenia)|Dnevnik]] and weekly political magazine [[Mladina]], two publications critical of the administration. By changing the laws governing the administration of the public broadcaster RTV Slovenia, the government enabled increased political control of the state media organisation's editorial board and its board of directors by increasing the number of board members appointed by the government.{{Cite news|url=https://www.rtvslo.si/referendum-o-rtv/kaj-prinasa-novi-zakon/43432|title=Kaj prinaša novi zakon?|work=Prvi interaktivni multimedijski portal, MMC RTV Slovenija|access-date=2018-06-03}} The law faced a referendum challenge, but was approved by a tight margin as it also promised to lower compulsory contributions for the broadcaster's funding.{{Cite web|url=https://www.24ur.com/novice/volitve/ce-iz-vseh-smetnjakov-po-mestih-gledajo-struce-kruha.html|title=Vsak dan prvi - 24ur.com|website=www.24ur.com|language=sl|access-date=2018-06-03}} In 2007, over five hundred journalists launched a petition against political pressures on the media. The petition accused premier Janša of limiting press freedom in particular, but was aimed against all infringements against press freedom by either government, political actors in general, or media company owners.{{Cite news|url=https://www.mladina.si/75880/04-10-2007-peticija_zoper_cenzuro_in_politicne_pritiske_na_novinarje_v_sloveniji/|title=Peticija zoper cenzuro in politične pritiske na novinarje v Sloveniji {{!}} MLADINA.si|work=Mladina.si|access-date=2018-06-03}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.dnevnik.si/271330|title=Slovenski novinarji zoper cenzuro|work=Dnevnik|access-date=2018-06-03}} The [[International Press Institute]] voiced support for the petition and called on the government to create an independent body to investigate the claims of media influence.{{Cite news|url=https://www.dnevnik.si/272383|title=Mednarodni novinarski inštitut poziva k preiskavi političnih pritiskov na slovenske medije|work=Dnevnik|access-date=2018-06-03}} SDS rejected accusations of impropriety, claiming the media was in fact controlled by leftist opposition groups.{{Cite news|url=https://www.dnevnik.si/285888|title=Jože Tanko (SDS): Nekatere medije nadzira Borut Pahor|work=Dnevnik|access-date=2018-06-03}} ==== Economy and finance ==== The first [[Cabinet of Janez Janša I|Cabinet of Janez Janša]] oversaw a period of rapid economic growth. GDP grew by nearly 5% between 2004 and 2006, reaching nearly 7% growth in 2007, making it the fastest-growing eurozone member for that year.{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-slovenia-pm/slovenia-parliament-confirms-jansa-as-prime-minister-idUSTRE80R0L720120128|title=Slovenia parliament confirms Jansa as prime minister|last=Novak|first=Marja|work=U.S.|access-date=2018-06-03|language=en-US}} The economic boom, however, was highly dependent on private debt, particularly corporate debt. The Ministry of Finance, headed by [[Andrej Bajuk]], passed comprehensive tax reform, lowering corporate taxes and taxes on juridical persons, and the tax burden on individual incomes, flattening income tax margin progression, and simplifying the tax code. It oversaw the implementation of the Euro, privatisation of state-owned NKBM bank, lowering public expenditure, and increasing budget surpluses.{{Cite news|url=https://www.dnevnik.si/337210|title=Dosežki ministrstva za finance po Bajuku: Davčna reforma, uvedba evra, predsedovanje EU, privatizacija NKBM in znižanje javne porabe|work=Dnevnik|access-date=2018-06-03}} === 2008–2011: in opposition === In the [[Slovenian parliamentary election, 2008|2008 parliamentary election]] (held on 21 September 2008) narrowly lost against the [[Social Democrats (Slovenia)|Social Democrats]], until then the main opposition party. It also lost one seat in Slovenian Parliament, falling to 28.{{Cite web|url=http://www.dvk-rs.si/index.php/si/arhiv-drzavni-zbor-rs/leto-2008|title=Državni zbor RS - Leto 2008 {{!}} Državna volilna komisija|website=Državna volilna komisija|access-date=2018-06-04}} With the election of the Social Democrat leader [[Borut Pahor]] as Prime Minister of Slovenia, the Slovenian Democratic Party officially declared it would stay in opposition and form a [[shadow cabinet]]. The shadow government was formed in late December 2008, and it includes several independent members as well as members from other conservative parties.{{cite web |url=http://www.sta.si/vest.php?s=s&id=1349433 |title=STA: SDS ustanovila strokovni svet |publisher=Sta.si |date=2008-12-23 |accessdate=2014-07-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714152831/http://www.sta.si/vest.php?s=s&id=1349433 |archivedate=2014-07-14 |df= }} In the [[European Parliament election, 2009 (Slovenia)|2009 European election]], the SDS was the most popular party in Slovenia with 26.9% of votes, more than eight points ahead of the second-most popular party, the ruling Social Democrats.{{Cite web|url=http://www.dvk-rs.si/index.php/si/arhiv-evropski-parlament/leto-2009|title=Volitve v Evropski parlament - Leto 2009 {{!}} Državna volilna komisija|website=Državna volilna komisija|access-date=2018-06-04}} In 2009, the MP [[Franc Pukšič]] left the Slovenian Democratic Party and joined the [[Slovenian People's Party]]; the SDS parliamentary group was thus reduced from 28 to 27 MPs.{{Cite news|url=http://www.rtvslo.si/slovenija/franc-puksic-iz-sds-a-v-sls/213371|title=Franc Pukšič iz SDS-a v SLS?|work=Prvi interaktivni multimedijski portal, MMC RTV Slovenija|access-date=2018-06-04}} === 2012–2013: a year in power (second Janša Cabinet) === In the [[Slovenian parliamentary election, 2011|2011 snap parliamentary election]] (held on 4 December after the centre-left governing coalition collapsed due to internal conflict and inefficacy in passing meaningful economic reforms), SDS won 26.19% of the vote, gaining 26 seats in the [[National Assembly (Slovenia)|National Assembly]], thus making SDS the second-largest parliamentary party after the newly formed [[centre-left]] party, [[Positive Slovenia]] (PS) (headed by Ljubljana mayor [[Zoran Janković (politician)|Zoran Janković]]), which won 28 MPs (28.5% of the total).{{Cite web|url=http://www.sloveniatimes.com/exit-poll-jankovic-wins-the-elections/2|title=Positive Slovenia Surprise Winner of Election|website=www.sloveniatimes.com|language=sl|access-date=2018-06-02}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-slovenia-pm/slovenia-parliament-confirms-jansa-as-prime-minister-idUSTRE80R0L720120128|title=Slovenia parliament confirms Jansa as prime minister|last=Novak|first=Marja|work=U.S.|access-date=2018-06-02|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.britannica.com/place/Slovenia/Government-and-society#ref1007089|title=Slovenia - Government and society|work=Encyclopedia Britannica|access-date=2018-06-03|language=en}} However, SDS succeeded in forming a ruling [[Cabinet of Janez Janša II|four-party coalition government]] (which included the [[Civic List (Slovenia)|Civic List]], [[New Slovenia]], [[Slovenian People's Party]], and [[Democratic Party of Pensioners of Slovenia]]) (holding a combined total of 50 out of 90 parliamentary seats) some two months after the election after PS failed to form a coalition with a parliamentary majority. The coalition took power amid an alarming economic downturn ([[European debt crisis]]), the worst in the independent country's history.{{citation needed|date=June 2018}} The country's economic woes were further exacerbated by credit agencies' lowering of Slovenia's credit rating amid the political tumult. The coalition, headed by SDS, undertook drastic economic and financial reforms in an attempt to halt the economic downturn. Finance Minister Janez Šuštaršič pledged to speed up privatisation of state enterprises, cut public spending, and reduce budget shortfalls.{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/slovenia-finmin-idUSFINMINSI20120215|title=PROFILE-Slovenia's Finance Minister Janez Sustersic|last=Editorial|first=Reuters|work=U.S.|access-date=2018-06-03|language=en-US}} Janša additionally pledged to cut taxes, remove regulations, lower the deficit, and raise the retirement age. The coalition passed laws transferring all state-owned enterprises into a single state holding company to accelerate privatisation efforts, and created a bad bank that would take on non-performing loans from the bad debt-ridden state-owned banks.{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-slovenia-reforms/slovenia-adopts-reform-laws-but-referendums-possible-idUSBRE89M1EP20121023|title=Slovenia adopts reform laws but referendums possible|last=Novak|first=Marja|work=U.S.|access-date=2018-06-02|language=en-US}} It intended to cut profit and income taxes to boost the economy,{{Cite web|url=http://www.sloveniatimes.com/there-is-no-choice|title=There is no Choice|website=www.sloveniatimes.com|language=sl|access-date=2018-06-02}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/slovenia-economy/slovenia-expects-eu-assessment-mission-in-april-finmin-idUSL5E8E89PS20120308|title=Slovenia expects EU assessment mission in April-finmin|last=Editorial|first=Reuters|work=U.S.|access-date=2018-06-02|language=en-US}} and enact [[Balanced budget amendment|constitutional changes demanding balance budgets]]. It also passed sweeping and highly contentious austerity measures (the Law of Public Finance Balance (Slovene: ''Zakon o uravnovešenju javnih financ (ZUJF)'')), and reportedly planned further cuts to state spending.{{Cite web|url=https://www.eurofound.europa.eu/observatories/eurwork/articles/industrial-relations/austerity-measures-cause-conflict|title=Austerity measures cause conflict {{!}} Eurofound|website=www.eurofound.europa.eu|language=en|access-date=2018-06-02}}{{Cite news|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2012-05-11/news/sns-rt-slovenia-budgeturgentl5e8gb69w-20120511_1_slovenia-austerity-measures-fiscal-gap|title=Recession-hit Slovenia adopts austerity measures|work=tribunedigital-chicagotribune|access-date=2018-06-02|language=en}} The ZUJF fiscal consolidation law included provisions lowering pensions (widely opposed by the public{{Cite web|url=http://www.sloveniatimes.com/poll-three-quarters-of-slovenians-say-pension-cuts-unjustified|title=Poll: Three Quarters of Slovenians Say Pension Cuts Unjustified|website=www.sloveniatimes.com|language=sl|access-date=2018-06-02}}), cutting wages for public sector employees, reducing education funding, social transfers and benefits.{{Cite web|url=http://www.sloveniatimes.com/national-assembly-starts-debate-on-austerity-bills|title=National Assembly Starts Debate on Austerity Bills|website=www.sloveniatimes.com|language=sl|access-date=2018-06-02}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-slovenia-austerity/slovenian-austerity-drive-threatened-by-referendum-call-idUSBRE84H09N20120518|title=Slovenian austerity drive threatened by referendum call|last=Novak|first=Marja|work=U.S.|access-date=2018-06-02|language=en-US}} The draft of the law sparked a public sector general strike, and the law faced the possibility of a referendum.{{Cite web|url=http://www.sloveniatimes.com/referendum-on-austerity-act|title=Referendum on Austerity Act?|website=www.sloveniatimes.com|language=sl|access-date=2018-06-02}} The SDS-led government proved impotent in stemming the economic troubles facing the nation. Despite the momentous reforms efforts, the economic troubles intensified, resulting in increasing levels of unemployment, plunging living standards, a fall in domestic spending, and large budget deficits.{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-slovenia-government/struggling-slovenia-to-appoint-new-pm-to-rescue-economy-idUSBRE91P0EE20130226|title=Struggling Slovenia to appoint new PM to rescue economy|last=Editorial|first=Reuters|work=U.S.|access-date=2018-06-02|language=en-US}} The fall in domestic demand, coupled with falling exports, resulted in a [[double dip recession]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-slovenia-protest/protests-in-slovenia-continue-despite-governments-fall-idUSBRE9280EU20130309|title=Protests in Slovenia continue despite government's fall|last=Novak|first=Marja|work=U.S.|access-date=2018-06-02|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-slovenia-protest/fresh-slovenian-protests-amid-bailout-fears-idUSBRE93Q05Y20130427|title=Fresh Slovenian protests amid bailout fears|last=Novak|first=Marja|work=U.S.|access-date=2018-06-03|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/financialcrisis/9960610/Slovenia-faces-contagion-from-Cyprus-as-banking-crisis-deepens.html|title=Slovenia faces contagion from Cyprus as banking crisis deepens|last=Evans-Pritchard|first=Ambrose|date=2013-03-28|access-date=2018-06-03|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}} A later report alleges that the sharp downturn in Slovenian economic outlook was a result of Janša's overdramatic public statements regarding the economic fitness of the nation. Janša reportedly made such ominous claims for political purposes as means of solidifying political power and as a negotiating strategy to strengthen his hand during negotiations with public sector unions. The PM's eerie pronouncements were taken at face value by foreign observers, however, creating a self-fulfilling feedback loop where gloomy statements made by top Slovene officials created more panic and dismay in the foreign press and various organisations, and vice versa, resulting in falling credit ratings and asset prices, and excessive capital injections/bailouts with funds borrowed at excessively high interest rates.{{Cite news|url=https://www.mladina.si/176754/kdo-je-pokopal-slovenijo/|title=Kdo je pokopal Slovenijo? {{!}} MLADINA.si|work=Mladina.si|access-date=2018-06-04}} Janša also faced graft charges even before ascending to the premiership in 2012. He was one of the defendants being tried for corruption as result of a [[Patria case|2006 bribery scandal]] involving charges of accepting kickbacks to fund his party's electoral campaign.{{Cite news|url=https://euobserver.com/investigations/123961|title=[Investigation] Arms deals and bribes: The downfall of Slovenia's former PM|access-date=2018-06-02|language=en}} In late 2012, [[2012–13 Maribor protests|protests began to take place]] in Slovenia's second largest city, Maribor, against its mayor and SDS ally, [[Franc Kangler]], who was being investigated due to allegations of corruption.{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-slovenia-protests/slovenia-as-star-wanes-anger-on-streets-idUSBRE8BJ0UU20121220|title=Slovenia: as star wanes, anger on streets|last=Radosavljevic|first=Zoran|work=U.S.|access-date=2018-06-02|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-slovenia-protests/violent-mass-protest-continue-in-slovenia-idUSBRE8B218Q20121203|title=Violent mass protest continue in Slovenia|last=Novak|first=Marja|work=U.S.|access-date=2018-06-02|language=en-US}} The protests soon picked up momentum and [[2012–13 Slovenian protests|spread across the country]], becoming the largest in the independent republic's history. Protestors' main grievances were the harsh austerity measures imposed by the ruling government, looming sale-offs of state enterprises, and allegations of widespread corruption among the ruling elite. The protests also saw the worst violence in the nation's history as an independent state, with small groups of young, violent extremists - likely members of far-right and hooligan groups - clashing with police.{{Cite web|url=http://www.dw.com/en/thousands-protest-against-austerity-in-slovenia/a-16387391|title=Thousands protest against austerity in Slovenia {{!}} DW {{!}} 18.11.2012|last=(www.dw.com)|first=Deutsche Welle|website=DW.COM|language=en|access-date=2018-06-02}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-slovenia-protest/slovenia-police-clash-with-protesters-ahead-of-vote-idUSBRE8AT1GD20121130|title=Slovenia police clash with protesters ahead of vote|last=Novak|first=Marja|work=U.S.|access-date=2018-06-02|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/anti-austerity-slovenia-protesters-clash-with-police-1.1298756|title=Anti-austerity Slovenia protesters clash with police {{!}} CBC News|work=CBC|access-date=2018-06-02|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-slovenia-arrests/slovenia-police-arrest-141-in-violent-anti-austerity-protests-idUSBRE8B30QM20121204|title=Slovenia police arrest 141 in violent anti-austerity protests|last=Editorial|first=Reuters|work=U.S.|access-date=2018-06-02|language=en-US}} In early 2013, the instability and public resentment was compounded after the [[Commission for the Prevention of Corruption of the Republic of Slovenia|Commission for the Prevention of Corruption]] revealed both PM Janez Janša and the leader of the largest opposition party (PS), [[Zoran Janković (politician)|Zoran Janković]], violated anti-corruption laws by failing to report or account for assets in their possession and received income/payments.{{Cite web|url=http://www.sloveniatimes.com/watchdog-finds-jansa-jankovic-in-violation-of-anti-graft-law|title=Watchdog Finds Janša, Janković in Violation of Anti-Graft Law|website=www.sloveniatimes.com|language=sl|access-date=2018-06-02}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-slovenia-crisis/slovenia-gripped-by-strike-government-on-the-ropes-idUSBRE90M0KQ20130123|title=Slovenia gripped by strike, government on the ropes|last=Novak|first=Marja|work=U.S.|access-date=2018-06-02|language=en-US}} Media reports alleging [[Slovenian Intelligence and Security Agency]] was "infiltrated" by members of SDS also surfaced.[http://www.mladina.si/119717/vdor-kadrov-sds-v-sovo/ An Intrusion of the Members of SDS into Sova] (In Slovene: "Vdor kadrov SDS v Sovo"), [[Mladina]], 18 January 2013 Amid continuing anti-government protests,{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-slovenia-protests/slovenia-protest-adds-pressure-to-crumbling-government-idUSBRE9170XI20130208|title=Slovenia protest adds pressure to crumbling government|last=Novak|first=Marja|work=U.S.|access-date=2018-06-02|language=en-US}} a strike of public sector workers, and the lowest public opinion ratings of any government in the nation's history,{{Cite web|url=http://www.ninamedia.si/drzavnizbor.php|title=Ninamedia - Arhiv anket|website=www.ninamedia.si|access-date=2018-06-22}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.delo.si/novice/politika/anketa-dela-stranke-z-vse-manjso-podporo.html|title=Anketa Dela: Stranke z vse manjšo podporo|last=politika|first=Marko Pečauer, notranja|access-date=2018-06-22|language=sl-si}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.delo.si/novice/politika/anketa-dela-velikanska-podpora-protikorupcijski-komisiji.html|title=Anketa Dela: Velikanska podpora protikorupcijski komisiji|last=politika|first=Marko Pečauer, notranja|access-date=2018-06-22|language=sl-si}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.mladina.si/120542/za-jansev-odhod/|title=Za Janšev odhod! {{!}} MLADINA.si|work=Mladina.si|access-date=2018-06-22}} coalition partners began to depart from the coalition.{{Cite web|url=http://www.delo.si/novice/politika/sls-ce-jansa-do-februarja-ne-odstopi-gremo-iz-koalicije-tudi-mi.html|title=SLS: če Janša do februarja ne odstopi gremo iz koalicije tudi mi|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} The government finally collapsed after a vote of no confidence, and a PS consensus candidate, [[Alenka Bratušek]], was appointed as PM despite continuing protests demanding a snap election.{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-slovenia-government/slovenian-coalition-party-asks-premier-to-resign-idUSBRE90B0FG20130112|title=Slovenian coalition party asks premier to resign|last=Novak|first=Marja|work=U.S.|access-date=2018-06-02|language=en-US}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.sloveniatimes.com/alenka-bratusek-new-pm-designate|title=Alenka Bratušek New PM-designate|website=www.sloveniatimes.com|language=sl|access-date=2018-06-02}} === 2013–: return to opposition === On 20 March 2013, the second Janša cabinet was replaced by the [[cabinet of Alenka Bratušek]], a four-party centre-left coalition led by the new leader of [[Positive Slovenia]], [[Alenka Bratušek]]. In June 2013, Janša was convicted in the [[Patria case]], but appealed the verdict. In April 2014, the Higher Court upheld the two-year jail sentence passed on Janez Janša as result of the bribery conviction.{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-slovenia-corruption/slovenian-court-confirms-jail-sentence-for-ex-pm-jansa-idUSBREA3R0UL20140428|title=Slovenian court confirms jail sentence for ex-PM Jansa|last=Editorial|first=Reuters|work=U.S.|access-date=2018-06-04|language=en-US}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.economist.com/eastern-approaches/2014/05/03/slovenias-fragile-recovery|title=Slovenia's fragile recovery|website=The Economist|language=en|access-date=2018-06-04}} In June of that year, Janša began serving out his sentence, 26 years after his imprisonment for leaking military secrets as a whistle-blower ([[JBTZ trial|his imprisonment, trial, and public reaction]] were a milestone in the Slovenian path to independence). Despite his imprisonment, Janša stood as candidate for MP.{{Cite web|url=http://www.sloveniatimes.com/after-26-years-jansa-in-prison-again|title=After 26 Years, Janša in Prison Again|website=www.sloveniatimes.com|language=sl|access-date=2018-06-04}} In the May [[European Parliament election, 2014|2014 European Parliament election]], SDS came in first place nationally, garnering 24.78% of the vote,{{cite web|url=http://www.delo.si/assets/info5/20140525/EUvolitve2014/volitve.html |title=EU volitve 2014 / 18 |publisher=Delo.si |date= |accessdate=2014-07-10}}{{cite web|url=http://www.volitve.gov.si/ep2014/en/rez_sl.html |title=European parliament elections 2014 |publisher=Volitve.gov.si |date=2014-05-25 |accessdate=2014-07-10}} and winning three [[Member of the European Parliament|MEP]] seats (out of eight allocated for Slovenia).{{cite web|url=http://www.volitve.gov.si/ep2014/en/rez_kan.html |title=European parliament elections 2014 |publisher=Volitve.gov.si |date=2014-05-25 |accessdate=2014-07-10}} The party received 20.69% of the vote in the [[Slovenian parliamentary election, 2014|snap Slovenian parliamentary election]] held on 13 July 2014, and won 21 seats in parliament.{{Cite web|url=http://volitve.gov.si/dz2014/en/index.html|title=Republic of Slovenia early elections for deputies to the national assembly 2014|website=volitve.gov.si|access-date=2018-06-04}} The party remained in opposition, this time to the [[cabinet of Miro Cerar]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.sloveniatimes.com/slovenia-with-new-government|title=Slovenia With New Government|website=www.sloveniatimes.com|language=sl|access-date=2018-06-04}} Janez Janša was reelected as MP despite being imprisoned. The Constitutional Court decided not to deprive Janša of his MP mandate, and Janša was allowed leave while carrying out his political functions.{{Cite news|url=https://www.rtvslo.si/slovenija/jansa-ni-smel-iz-zapora-saj-ni-pojasnil-kaj-bo-pocel/352105|title=Janša ni smel iz zapora, saj ni pojasnil, kaj bo počel|work=Prvi interaktivni multimedijski portal, MMC RTV Slovenija|access-date=2018-06-04}} The Constitutional Court suspended Janša's jail sentence in December, pending the ruling regarding his appeal of the Patria verdict.{{Cite news|url=http://www.delo.si/novice/politika/jansa-ni-vec-zapornik.html|title=Janša za zdaj izpuščen iz zapora|last=Delo.si|first=Peter Jančič, notranja politika, Ni. Č., Pi. K.,|access-date=2018-06-04|language=sl-si}} The Constitutional Court decided to annul the Higher Court's decision in April 2015, returning it to the lower courts for retrial.{{Cite news|url=https://www.dnevnik.si/1042711773|title=Ustavno sodišče razveljavilo dveletno zaporno kazen Janezu Janši|work=Dnevnik|access-date=2018-06-04}} In September of the same year, the statute of limitations of the Patria case expired.{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-slovenia-corruption/slovenian-bribery-trial-against-ex-pm-jansa-expires-idUSKCN0R71KC20150907|title=Slovenian bribery trial against ex-PM Jansa expires|last=Editorial|first=Reuters|work=U.S.|access-date=2018-06-04|language=en-US}} SDS representatives expressed the belief that the trial was politically motivated and that the imprisonment of the party frontman unfairly hindered their election efforts, declaring the elections illegitimate and "stolen", and demanded fresh elections.{{Cite web|url=http://www.sloveniatimes.com/insulted-and-defeated-sds-party-irrationally-smearing-their-own-country|title=Insulted and Defeated SDS Party Irrationally Smearing Their Own Country|website=www.sloveniatimes.com|language=sl|access-date=2018-06-04}}{{Cite news|url=https://siol.net/novice/slovenija/jansa-na-sodiscu-volitve-2014-so-bile-ukradene-461818|title=SDS toži državo: "Volitve 2014 so bile ukradene"|access-date=2018-06-04|language=sl}} In 2018, SDS sued the state for alleged financial damages the party incurred due to the alleged election "theft".{{Cite web|url=https://english.sta.si/2440354/sds-patria-damages-trial-starting|title=STA: SDS Patria damages trial starting|website=english.sta.si|language=en|access-date=2018-06-04}} With a campaign largely based on anti-immigration populist rhetoric, SDS topped public opinion polls heading into the 2018 parliamentary election. The incendiary electoral campaign sparked a rally under the title "Without Fear — Against the Politics of Hatred", with some 2,000-3,000 heart-shaped balloon-carrying marchers in attendance.{{Cite news|url=https://www.vecer.com/spremljamo-v-ljubljani-protest-proti-sirjenju-sovrastva-6484656|title=(VIDEO in FOTO) Več tisoč ljudi na shodu proti politiki sovraštva|work=Časnik Večer d.o.o.|access-date=2018-06-07|language=sl-si}}{{Cite news|url=https://siol.net/novice/slovenija/protest-v-ljubljani-sejanje-strahu-sovraznost-in-lazi-vodi-v-totalitarizem-foto-469020|title=Protest v Ljubljani: "Sejanje strahu, sovražnosti in laži vodi v totalitarizem" #foto|access-date=2018-06-07|language=sl}} During the 2018 electoral campaign, SDS also begun to send postable questionnaires ("voter consults") to Slovene households. The questionnaires contained loaded questions and proposals (e.g. "... Do you support SDS's proposal that the healthcare system be set in order?"). The effort was apparently part of the party's electoral campaign, and likely fashioned on Hungarian "national consultations", which the country's ruling party has practiced for years.{{Cite news|url=https://www.mladina.si/185151/posvetovanje-s-prevaro/|title=Posvetovanje s prevaro {{!}} MLADINA.si|work=Mladina.si|access-date=2018-06-10}}{{Cite news|url=https://vezjak.com/2018/05/28/dilema-izsiljene-izbire-ste-za-bozicnico/|title=Dilema izsiljene izbire: »Ste za božičnico?«|date=2018-05-28|work=::: IN MEDIA RES :::|access-date=2018-06-10|language=sl-SI}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/76ce19e4-a768-11e7-93c5-648314d2c72c|title=Subscribe to read|website=Financial Times|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-06-10}} SDS once again emerged as winner in the [[Slovenian parliamentary election, 2018|2018 parliamentary election]], garnering 24.92% of the vote and winning 25 MP seats.{{Cite web|url=http://volitve.gov.si/dz2018/#/rezultati|title=http://volitve.gov.si/dz2018/#/rezultati|last=d.o.o.|first=SRC|website=volitve.gov.si|access-date=2018-06-17}} President Borut Pahor announced he would afford Janša the mandate to form a coalition government, however, it appeared unlikely he would be successful in doing so, most parties having declared they do not intend to enter into a coalition with SDS. Janša declared he would be willing to relinquish his post as PM designate to some other SDS MP if this would ease tensions and enable SDS to form a coalition government. The second largest party, the [[List of Marjan Šarec]], said it had already started informal talks to form a coalition excluding SDS days after the election.{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-slovenia-government/slovenias-president-to-give-mandate-to-anti-immigrant-party-to-form-government-idUSKCN1J31SI|title=Slovenia's president to give mandate to anti-immigrant party to...|last=Novak|first=Marja|work=U.S.|access-date=2018-06-17|language=en-US}} Some two weeks after the 2018 election, Janša again met with Hungarian PM Orban during a private visit in Budapest. Janša and Orban also held a conference call with US president [[Donald Trump]] during the meeting.{{Cite web|url=https://english.sta.si/2526124/sds-head-jansa-pays-visit-to-hungarian-pm-orban|title=STA: SDS head Janša pays visit to Hungarian PM Orban|website=english.sta.si|language=en|access-date=2018-06-17}} === Shadow Cabinet === In July 2015 Slovenian Democratic Party, as the biggest party of the official opposition, formed The Shadow Cabinet, which is actually a party structure. Members of the Shadow Cabinet are the following:{{citation needed|date=June 2018}} * President: [[Janez Janša]] (former Prime Minister, former President of the European Council, former Minister of Defence, President of the Slovenian Democratic Party, MP) * Finance: [[Andrej Šircelj]] (former State Secretary, MP) * Justice: [[Vinko Gorenak]] (former Minister of Interior, former State Secretary, MP) * Foreign Affairs: [[Milan Zver]] (former Minister of Education, MEP) * Economical Development and Technology: [[Andrej Vizjak]] (former Minister of Economy, former Minister of Labour, Family and Social Affairs, former State Secretary, former MP) * Labour, Family and Social Affairs: [[Romana Tomc]] (former State Secretary, former Deputy Speaker, former MP, MEP) * Education, Science and Sport: [[Borut Rončević]] (university professor) * Culture: [[Vasko Simoniti]] (former Minister of Culture, university professor) * Defence: [[Aleš Hojs]] (former Minister of Defence) * Infrastructure and Spatial Planning: [[Zvonko Černač]] (former Minister of Infrastructure, former MP, Vice-president of the Slovenian Democratic Party) * Agriculture and Environment: [[Matjaž Kočar]] (former State Secretary) * Interior: [[Božo Predalič]] (former Secretary-General of the Government) * Public Administration: [[Fidel Krupič]] * Health: [[Alenka Forte]] * Slovenians Abroad and Slovenians in Neighbouring Countries: [[Miro Petek]] (former MP) == Ideology == === Populism === During the [[European migrant crisis]], SDS sharply intensified its nationalist populist rhetoric.{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/jun/01/drain-the-swamp-rightwing-leader-pulls-ahead-in-slovenias-polls|title='Drain the swamp': rightwing leader pulls ahead in Slovenia's polls|last=MacDowall|first=Andrew|date=2018-06-01|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-06-02}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.euronews.com/2018/06/01/explained-slovenia-s-elections-and-orban-s-populist-influence|title=Explained: Slovenia's election and Orban's populist influence|date=2018-06-01|work=euronews|access-date=2018-06-02|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/03/world/europe/slovenia-election.html|title=Slovenia Elections Tilt Another European Country to the Right|date=2018-06-03|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-06-04|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} The party came out in opposition of migrant quotas and advocated shifting resources from non-governmental organisations to increase security spending.{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-slovenia-election/anti-immigrant-stance-helps-slovenias-sds-party-to-poll-lead-idUSKCN1IN1QU|title=Anti-immigrant stance helps Slovenia's SDS party to poll lead|last=Novak|first=Marja|work=U.S.|access-date=2018-06-02|language=en-US}} Janša furthermore lambasted the "degenerate left".{{Cite news|url=http://www.delo.si/sobotna/najprej-slovenija-kaj-pa-potem.html|title=Najprej Slovenija. Kaj pa potem?|last=Markeš|first=Janez|access-date=2018-06-05|language=sl-si}} The party's heated rhetoric and allegations of corrupt practices have led "to concerns among international observers about the direction of Slovenia, which is generally regarded as a regional success story" as SDS topped [[Opinion polling for the Slovenian parliamentary election, 2018|opinion polls]] heading into the 2018 parliamentary election. The party has also co-opted US President Donald Trump's populist rhetoric, with Janša and the party frequently echoing Trump's catchphrases "drain the swamp", "deep state",{{Cite news|url=http://www.demokracija.si/komentar/ali-v-sloveniji-obstaja-globoka-drzava.html|title=Ali v Sloveniji obstaja globoka država?|last=Umek|first=prof. dr. Andrej|access-date=2018-06-04|language=sl-si}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.mladina.si/45132/globoka-drzava/|title=Globoka država {{!}} MLADINA.si|work=Mladina.si|access-date=2018-06-04}} and "fake news".{{Cite news|url=https://www.politico.eu/article/slovenian-survivor-targets-victory-a-la-orban/|title=Slovenian survivor targets victory à la Orbán|date=2018-06-01|work=POLITICO|access-date=2018-06-02|language=en-US}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.dw.com/en/orban-ally-janez-jansa-expected-to-top-slovenias-election/a-44055791|title=Orban ally Janez Jansa expected to top Slovenia's election {{!}} DW {{!}} 02.06.2018|last=(www.dw.com)|first=Deutsche Welle|website=DW.COM|language=en|access-date=2018-06-05}} The party has also proposed requiring that for each new regulation, two existing regulations must be repealed,{{Cite web|url=https://www.sds.si/novica/janez-jansa-za-vsak-nov-predpis-naj-se-dva-ukine-13794|title=Janez Janša: Za vsak nov predpis naj se dva ukine! {{!}} SDS|website=www.sds.si|language=sl|access-date=2018-06-02}} a proposal notably advocated for and enacted by Trump.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/business/archive/2017/01/trumps-regulation-eo/515007/|title=Trump’s 'Two-for-One' Regulation Executive Order|last=Lam|first=Bourree|date=2017-01-30|work=The Atlantic|access-date=2018-06-02|language=en-US}} Janša has also used the phrase "Slovenia first" on several occasions.{{Cite news|url=https://www.rtvslo.si/slovenija/jansa-najprej-slovenija-potem-drugi/446321|title=Janša: Najprej Slovenija, potem drugi|work=Prvi interaktivni multimedijski portal, MMC RTV Slovenija|access-date=2018-06-07}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.total-slovenia-news.com/politics/1045-elections-2018-party-profiles-sds-the-janez-jansa-party-feature|title=Elections 2018, Party Profiles: SDS, the Janez Janša Party (Feature)|access-date=2018-07-03|language=en-gb}} === Domestic policy === ==== Economic policy ==== SDS has been described as broadly pro-market, and its economic policies have been characterised as [[Neoliberalism|neoliberal]]. SDS advocates for lower taxes and speeding up privatisation efforts.{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/jun/03/anti-immigration-party-leads-exit-poll-in-slovenian-election|title=Slovenian nationalist party set for power after winning election|last=Agencies|date=2018-06-04|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-06-05}} ==== Social policy ==== SDS introduced legislation allowing for same-sex civil unions while in government, but has opposed recognition of same-sex marriages.{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-slovenia-rights/slovenia-rejects-same-sex-marriages-in-a-referendum-idUSKBN0U30BS20151220|title=Slovenia rejects same-sex marriages in a referendum|last=Novak|first=Marja|work=U.S.|access-date=2018-06-05|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/12/22/world/europe/slovenians-deliver-major-setback-to-same-sex-marriage-in-vote.html|title=Slovenians Deliver Major Setback to Same-Sex Marriage in Referendum|date=2015-12-21|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-06-05|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} ==== Education policy ==== SDS advocates for the introduction of educational programs that would foster patriotism "from kindergarten through high school".{{Cite news|url=http://www.delo.si/novice/politika/tudi-sds-za-domoljubno-vzgojo-od-vrtca-do-srednje-sole.html|title=Tudi SDS za domoljubno vzgojo od vrtca do srednje šole|last=STA|first=Pi. K., Delo.si,|access-date=2018-06-07|language=sl-si}} The party supports full public financing of private school compulsory programs.{{Cite web|url=https://english.sta.si/2477065/sds-proposal-for-full-funding-of-private-schools-rejected|title=STA: SDS proposal for full funding of private schools rejected|website=english.sta.si|language=en|access-date=2018-06-07}} ==== National security ==== In early 2016, SDS proposed the establishment of a national guard composed of some 25,000 "patriotic" volunteers. The guard would replace all current reserve formations of the Slovene armed forces, would be under direct command of the general staff, and would be mobilised during natural disasters or during "altered national security states" (like the European refugee crisis, which was ongoing at the time). Both sexes could enlist. MP Žan Mahnič stated the establishment of the formation was a priority of the party's electoral platform. The proposal was prompted by worsening global national security prospects, in part due to the migrant crisis, a SDS representative said.{{Cite news|url=https://www.rtvslo.si/slovenija/sds-bi-25-000-domoljubov-zdruzil-v-nacionalni-gardi/383775|title=SDS bi 25.000 domoljubov združil v nacionalni gardi|work=Prvi interaktivni multimedijski portal, MMC RTV Slovenija|access-date=2018-06-07}} Government representatives argued that such a formation is unnecessary as the current reserve formations are sufficient.{{Cite news|url=https://www.rtvslo.si/slovenija/zl-nacionalno-gardo-vidi-kot-desnicarsko-paravojsko-nsi-idejo-podpira/383871|title=ZL nacionalno gardo vidi kot "desničarsko paravojsko", NSi idejo podpira|work=Prvi interaktivni multimedijski portal, MMC RTV Slovenija|access-date=2018-06-07}} ==== Judiciary and law enforcement ==== SDS advocates for trials to be open to the public (except in special circumstances).{{Cite web|url=https://www.sds.si/zate/program|title=Program ZATE - Za pravično sojenje {{!}} SDS|website=www.sds.si|language=sl|access-date=2018-06-10}} ==== Other policies ==== SDS has long advocated for a change in the Slovene parliamentary electoral system, namely the shift from the current [[proportional electoral system]] to two-round [[plurality voting]]. SDS argues this would result in more stable and effective governments.{{Cite web|url=https://www.sds.si/en/about-sds/programme|title=About SDS - Programme {{!}} SDS|website=www.sds.si|language=en|access-date=2018-06-10}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.dnevnik.si/1042573817|title=Za SDS večinski volilni sistem rešitev vseh težav|work=Dnevnik|access-date=2018-06-10}} SDS supports citizens' legal right to bear arms, and has come out in opposition to further restrictions. It strongly opposed new EU regulation of firearms which the European Commission moved to pass after the [[November 2015 Paris attacks|2015 Paris terrorist attacks]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.domovina.je/sds-proti-predlogu-za-otezitev-dostopa-do-orozja/|title=SDS proti predlogu za otežitev dostopa do orožja {{!}} Domovina|last=Uredništvo|website=www.domovina.je|language=sl-SI|access-date=2018-06-07}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.sta.si/2215016/sds-zaradi-predloga-za-otezitev-dostopa-do-orozja-za-izredno-sejo-odbora-dz|title=STA: SDS zaradi predloga za otežitev dostopa do orožja za izredno sejo odbora DZ|website=www.sta.si|language=sl|access-date=2018-06-07}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.rtvslo.si/evropska-unija/evroposlanci-sprejeli-strozjo-zakonodajo-o-orozju/417322|title=Evroposlanci sprejeli strožjo zakonodajo o orožju|work=Prvi interaktivni multimedijski portal, MMC RTV Slovenija|access-date=2018-06-07}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.mladina.si/171786/ljudska-obramba/|title=Ljudska obramba Prešeren's]] [[Zdravljica|A Toast]] ("Blessed be all nations/Which yearn to see the light of day/When where'er the Sun doth wander/The lands' strife shall be cast away/And when free every kinsman will be/Not fiends, only neighbours in foreigners we'll see!")—is "too internationalistic, and insufficiently patriotic", and advocates other stanzas from Prešeren's poem be added as text to the official anthem.{{Cite news|url=https://www.rtvslo.si/slovenija/kot-himno-bomo-se-peli-7-kitico-presernove-zdravljice/259929|title=Kot himno bomo še peli 7. kitico Prešernove Zdravljice|work=Prvi interaktivni multimedijski portal, MMC RTV Slovenija|access-date=2018-06-21}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.rtvslo.si/slovenija/retroaktivnost-v-predlogu-sds-a-o-nezastarljivosti-umora-neustavna/331314|title=Retroaktivnost v predlogu SDS-a o nezastarljivosti umora "neustavna"|work=Prvi interaktivni multimedijski portal, MMC RTV Slovenija|access-date=2018-06-21}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.delo.si/novice/politika/poslanci-nasprotujejo-spremembam-zakona-o-drzavnih-simbolih.html|title=SDS znova neuspešna s predlogom zakona o državnih simbolih|last=STA|first=Ni. Č., Delo.si,|access-date=2018-06-21|language=sl-si}} The party also advocates banning "all public expression of ideas through use of totalitarian symbols" and "all public displays of affection for totalitarian regimes". The party has denied accusations that it is merely attempting to outlaw the [[red star]],{{Cite news|url=https://www.rtvslo.si/slovenija/rdeca-zvezda-in-himna-ostajata-glasbene-kvote-ne-bodo-zvisane/356835|title=Rdeča zvezda in himna ostajata, glasbene kvote ne bodo zvišane|work=Prvi interaktivni multimedijski portal, MMC RTV Slovenija|access-date=2018-06-21}} which was the symbol of the [[Slovene Partisans]] during WWII,{{Cite news|url=https://www.mladina.si/153846/prepoved-rdece-zvezde/|title=Prepoved rdeče zvezde {{!}} MLADINA.si|work=Mladina.si|access-date=2018-06-21}} and is still often used in the Slovenian public sphere,{{Cite news|url=https://www.dnevnik.si/1042595774|title=Rdeča zvezda je spet razdvajala (foto)|work=Dnevnik|access-date=2018-06-21}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.delo.si/lokalno/ljubljana-in-okolica/dan-ko-je-sijala-rdeca-zvezda-54072.html|title=FOTO:Dan, ko je sijala rdeča zvezda|last=R.|first=Z.|access-date=2018-06-21|language=sl-si}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.primorske.si/slovenija/nosil-bom-rdeco-zvezdo-s-svetlano-makarovic-na-cel|title=Nosil bom rdečo zvezdo s Svetlano Makarovič na čelu ponovno na Kongresnem trgu|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} including as a symbol/logo of political and [[The Left (Slovenia)|parliamentary parties]].{{Cite web|url=http://dsd.si/|title=Vstopna|website=Združena levica - Demokratična stranka dela {{!}} ZL-DSD|language=sl-SI|access-date=2018-06-21}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.dnevnik.si/1042776276|title=Pod rdečo zvezdo rojena Levica ne bo večna opozicija|work=Dnevnik|access-date=2018-06-21}} The proposed law would not, on the other hand, ban wearing Nazi uniforms in public or displaying symbols associated with the Nazi-aligned anti-Partisan [[Slovene Home Guard]]. === Foreign policy === The party is pro-European, but staunchly anti-immigration and strongly opposed to EU asylum quotas. === Post-communist cabal conspiracy === Perhaps the most peculiar aspect of SDS ideology are the unique beliefs and rhetoric frequently employed by members of the party. The central tenet of the party's view regarding the country's political situation is that a sinister clique composed mostly of leftist former communist party officials has retained significant control over the economic, financial, political, social, judicial, and journalistic aspects of Slovenian public life. Some of the beliefs and language used are also shared by other right-wing populist political actors, or have entered into the mainstream political discourse.{{Cite web|url=https://english.sta.si/2245524/slovenian-political-metaphors-and-metonymy-a-guide|title=STA: Slovenian political metaphors and metonymy - a guide|website=english.sta.si|language=en|access-date=2018-06-04}}{{Citation needed|date=June 2018}} SDS members and affiliates frequently employ particular phrases and concepts to represent their world-view, most notably: * "Udbomafia" (from [[UDBA]], the Yugoslav secret police service) – a portmanteau neologism coined in the early 1990s to refer to an alleged cabal of former [[League of Communists of Slovenia|Slovenian Communist Party]] members, and UDBA informants and collaborators that supposedly still hold the reigns of economic and political control. The phrase is often used by SDS and affiliated publications.{{Cite news|url=http://nova24tv.si/news/have-you-heard-of-kucans-clan-a-mafia-like-group-from-the-league-of-communists-whose-aim-was-to-economically-control-slovenia-after-its-independence-and-assure-the-survival-of-thei/|title=Have you heard of Kučan's clan – a mafia-like group from the League of Communists, whose aim was to economically control Slovenia after its independence and assure the survival of their children? Majer also claims that the roughly 1/3 of Janković voters of Slovenian descent were ordered to vote for PS by Milan Kučan and Janez Stanovnik.{{Cite news|url=http://www.sds.si/news/10328|title=Jankovića sta dvignila umetno ustvarjen strah in slovenska radodarnost z državljanstvi|last=Majer|first=Tomaž|date=2011-12-09|work=www.sds.si|access-date=|archive-url=http://web.archive.org/web/20111211105751/http://www.sds.si/news/10328|archive-date=2011-12-11}} Several media organisations attempted to identify the author, but were unsuccessful.{{Cite news|url=http://old.slovenskenovice.si/novice/slovenija/kunstelj-pravi-da-je-tomaz-majer-jansa|title=Kunstelj pravi, da je Tomaž Majer Janša|last=|first=|date=2011-12-13|work=Slovenske novice|access-date=2018-06-06|language=sl}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.dnevnik.si/1042494881|title=Kdo je Tomaž Majer?|last=|first=|date=2011-12-13|work=Dnevnik|access-date=2018-06-06|language=sl}} It has been speculated that the real author of the text was in fact Janez Janša, based on similar known past statements (specifically, his 1993 commentary on the poor electoral performance of SDS during the 1992 elections). In the wake of the 2011 election, Janša and several other SDS MPs and candidates expressed similar but somewhat toned-down nationalistic sentiments while commenting on the election and its winner. The public reaction culminated in a "March of the Tracksuits", a rally where participants attended clothed in tracksuits to protest against division and intolerance. Lucija Šikovec Ušaj, a prominent Slovene lawyer, SDS MP candidate during the 2018 parliamentary election, and regular columnist on SDS-affiliated Nova24TV{{Cite web|url=http://nova24tv.si/oznaka/lucija-sikovec-usaj/|title=Lucija Šikovec Ušaj {{!}} Nova24TV|website=nova24tv.si|language=sl-SI|access-date=2018-07-06}} has on multiple occasions voiced opinions favourable to neo-nazis through her tweets. Steve King refuses to delete Nazi-sympathizer retweet|last=|first=|date=2018-06-27|website=Washington Post|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-08-03}} with Ušaj's retweet later also retweeted by Janša.{{Citation needed|date=June 2018}} == Organization and political affiliation == As of 2013, SDS membership numbered some 30,000 strong, more than any other political party in Slovenia.{{Cite web|url=https://reporter.si/clanek/slovenija/sds-z-vec-kot-30000-clani-dl-jih-ima-komaj-921-446352|title=SDS z več kot 30.000 člani, DL jih ima komaj 921|website=Revija Reporter|language=sl-SI|access-date=2018-06-05}} [[Slovenian Democratic Youth]] ({{lang-sl|Slovenska demokratska mladina}}, SDM) is the independent and autonomous [[youth wing]] of the party.{{Cite news|url=http://www.sdm.si/program/|title=Program|work=Slovenska demokratska mladina|access-date=2018-06-03|language=sl-si}} The party is affiliated with the [[Jože Pučnik Institute]], the major [[liberal conservatism|liberal-conservative]] think tank in Slovenia.{{Cite news|url=https://www.martenscentre.eu/members/jo%C5%BEe-pucnik-institute|title=Jože Pucnik Institute {{!}} Martens Centre|work=Martens Centre|access-date=2018-06-04|language=en}}{{Cite web|url=http://institutpucnik.si/|title=Inštitut dr. Jožeta Pučnika|website=institutpucnik.si|language=sl-SI|access-date=2018-06-04}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.mladina.si/90846/institut-dr-jozeta-pucnika/|title=Inštitut dr. Jožeta Pučnika|work=Mladina.si|access-date=2018-06-04}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.dnevnik.si/1042598110|title=Davkoplačevalci izdatno financirali zasebni inštitut SDS|work=Dnevnik|access-date=2018-06-04}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.mladina.si/95396/joze-pucnik-kot-by-pass/|title=Jože Pučnik kot by-pass|work=Mladina.si|access-date=2018-06-04}} It is also closely affiliated with the civic platform [[Rally for the Republic (Slovenia)|Rally for the Republic]] ({{lang|sl|Zbor za republiko}}).{{Cite news|url=https://www.dnevnik.si/1042575432|title=V SDS potrdili, da bo udeležence Zbora za republiko nagovoril tudi Janša, čeprav naj bi bil takrat v Bruslju|work=Dnevnik|access-date=2018-06-04}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.rtvslo.si/slovenija/zbor-za-republiko-volivce-nagovarja-k-podpori-sds-a-nsi-ja-in-sls-a/454965|title=Zbor za republiko volivce nagovarja k podpori SDS-a, NSi-ja in SLS-a|work=Prvi interaktivni multimedijski portal, MMC RTV Slovenija|access-date=2018-06-04}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.24ur.com/sds-nismo-organizatorji-zborovanja-se-ga-bomo-pa-z-veseljem-udelezili.html|title='SDS pripravlja zborovanje pod krinko Zbora za republiko'|website=www.24ur.com|language=sl|access-date=2018-06-04}} Committee 2014 (Slovene: ''Odbor 2014'') is a civic organisation that was established to protest and demand the overturn of the corruption convictions in the [[Patria case]], the freeing of SDS leader Janez Janša from prison (sentence resuling from the conviction), and the "actual implementation of the rule of law, human rights, basic freedoms, and establishment of a democratic society".{{Cite web|url=http://odbor2014.si/sub/296/o-nas|title=O nas|website=odbor2014.si|language=en|access-date=2018-06-04}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.mladina.si/160375/politika-pred-sodiscem/|title=Politika pred sodiščem|work=Mladina.si|access-date=2018-06-04}} Committee 2014 held regular protests in front of the Higher Court building in Ljubljana. The Alliance for the Values of Slovene Independence (Slovene: ''Združenje za vrednote Slovenske osamosvojitve'', VSO) is a patriotic veteran non-governmental organisation intended to commemorate the values of the Slovenian independence movement.{{Cite web|url=http://www.vso.si/index.php/vso/statut|title=Statut|last=User|first=Super|website=www.vso.si|language=sl-SI|access-date=2018-06-04}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.mladina.si/152646/cigave-vrednote/|title=Čigave vrednote?|work=Mladina.si|access-date=2018-06-04}} VSO leadership consists of prominent SDS members and associates. F., STA, N.|access-date=2018-06-04|language=sl-si}} SDS has seen some support from the Slovene Catholic Church. Damijan]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.mladina.si/43635/metamorfoze-jozeta-p-damijana/|title=Metamorfoze Jožeta P. Damijana {{!}} MLADINA.si|work=Mladina.si|access-date=2018-06-02}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.mladina.si/95355/dokoncno-slovo-mladoekonomistov/|title=Dokončno slovo mladoekonomistov {{!}} MLADINA.si|work=Mladina.si|access-date=2018-06-02}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.delo.si/novice/slovenija/damijan-nepreklicno-odstopil.html|title=Damijan nepreklicno odstopil|last=Uredništvo|access-date=2018-06-02|language=sl-si}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.rtvslo.si/slovenija/joze-p-damijan-vendarle-odstopil/51782|title=Jože P. Damijan vendarle odstopil|work=Prvi interaktivni multimedijski portal, MMC RTV Slovenija|access-date=2018-06-02}} [[Miha Brejc]] became ''persona non grata'' after his son-in-law [[Gregor Virant]] distanced himself from Janša and established the [[Civic List (Slovenia)|Civic List]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.mladina.si/112267/miha-brejc-izstopil-iz-sds/|title=Miha Brejc izstopil iz SDS {{!}} MLADINA.si|work=Mladina.si|access-date=2018-06-03}} Former public supporters also include sportsman [[Miran Pavlin]]. == Controversies and criticism == === Ties to extremist groups === SDS has been criticised for alleged links to a neo-Nazi extremist group; [[Far-right politics in Slovenia#Blood & Honour|the Slovene branch of Blood & Honour]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/greenslade/2014/sep/15/press-freedom-slovenia|title=Slovenian journalist facing jail for revealing party's neo-Nazi links|last=Greenslade|first=Roy|date=2014-09-15|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-06-02}} The journalist who uncovered the links (Anuška Delić) was charged with leaking confidential information. The state intelligence agency, [[Slovenian Intelligence and Security Agency|SOVA]], headed by an SDS appointee at the time of the indictment,{{Cite news|url=https://www.mladina.si/160578/neonacisti-na-varnem/|title=Neonacisti na varnem {{!}} MLADINA.si|work=Mladina.si|access-date=2018-06-02}} inadvertently confirmed allegations made by Delić by stating that the information revealed in the reports was consistent with findings of an ongoing investigation into the activities of the violent extremist group.{{Cite news|url=http://www.delo.si/novice/politika/ugotovitve-do-katerih-je-prislo-delo-sova-potrjuje.html|title=Neonacisti pri nas: Sova potrjuje ugotovitve Dela|last=politika|first=Mario Belovič, Rok Kajzer, notranja|access-date=2018-06-02|language=sl-si}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.delo.si/novice/slovenija/zaradi-razkrivanja-neonacisticne-mreze-preganjajo-novinarko-dela.html|title=Zaradi razkrivanja neonacistične mreže preganjajo novinarko Dela|last=kronika|first=Klara Škrinjar, notranja politika, Iva Ropac,|access-date=2018-06-02|language=sl-si}} SOVA argued that the information revealed in the reports could not have been obtained by any other means than by gaining access to information collected during the agency's covert investigations, and that the publication disrupted its efforts to monitor the group by alerting B & H of the monitoring efforts.{{Cite news|url=https://www.dnevnik.si/1042688464|title=Predobravnavni narok zoper Delićevo: predlagali zaslišanje Türka, Pahorja in Masleše|work=Dnevnik|access-date=2018-06-02}}{{Cite news|url=https://siol.net/novice/crna-kronika/nekdanja-direktorja-sove-razkrivanje-tajnih-podatkov-lahko-ogrozi-zivljenja-67863|title=Nekdanja direktorja Sove: Razkrivanje tajnih podatkov lahko ogrozi življenja|access-date=2018-06-02|language=sl}} Delić alleged the charges were "politically motivated".{{Cite news|url=https://www.rtvslo.si/crna-kronika/anuska-delic-ovadba-je-politicno-motivirana/355056|title=Anuška Delić: Ovadba je politično motivirana|work=Prvi interaktivni multimedijski portal, MMC RTV Slovenija|access-date=2018-06-02}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.dnevnik.si/1042702263|title=Anuška Delić: ovadba je politično motivirana, tožilstvo bi moralo postopek ustaviti|work=Dnevnik|access-date=2018-06-02}} Some Blood & Honour members were allegedly also members of SDS,{{Cite news|url=https://www.dnevnik.si/1042492052|title=Nasprotujoče si informacije: So v SDS-ov podmladek včlanjeni tudi neonacisti?|work=Dnevnik|access-date=2018-06-03}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.delo.si/ozadja/v-blizini-neonacistov-in-vrha-politike.html|title=V bližini neonacistov in vrha politike|last=Ozadja|first=Anuška Delić, Rok Kajzer,|access-date=2018-06-03|language=sl-si}} and formally met with SDS MP Branko Grims.{{Cite news|url=http://www.delo.si/novice/politika/ugotovitve-do-katerih-je-prislo-delo-sova-potrjuje.html|title=Neonacisti pri nas: Sova potrjuje ugotovitve Dela|last=politika|first=Mario Belovič, Rok Kajzer, notranja|access-date=2018-06-03|language=sl-si}} The group (the members of which allegedly received training by members of the Slovenian armed forces on an army [[Proving ground|training area]], borrowed army weaponry (a rocket launcher), attempted to purchase handguns, and were in direct correspondence with [[Anders Behring Breivik|Anders Breivik]] by both mail and e-mail, with multiple B & H members receiving his manifesto before Breivik's killing spree{{Cite news|url=https://www.mladina.si/160578/neonacisti-na-varnem/|title=Neonacisti na varnem {{!}} MLADINA.si|work=Mladina.si|access-date=2018-06-03}}) was allegedly intimately implicated in orchestrating the violent riots which took place amid the [[2012–13 Slovenian protests]]. The organised group of violent agitators that disrupted a major protest in Ljubljana was also suspected of having been trained, hired, and compensated, possibly by a political party, according to unofficial sources within the police.{{Cite news|url=https://www.mladina.si/118519/neonacisti-so-tu/|title=Neonacisti so tu {{!}} MLADINA.si|work=Mladina.si|access-date=2018-06-03}} More recently, SDS has also fostered close ties with [[Far-right politics in Slovenia#Generation Identity Slovenia|Generation Identity Slovenia]], the Slovenian chapter of the far-right [[Identitarian movement]] organisations.{{Cite news|url=https://siol.net/novice/slovenija/generacija-identitete-skrajno-gibanje-ki-je-z-volitvami-v-sloveniji-dobilo-nov-zagon-467050|title=Generacija identitete: skrajno gibanje, ki je z volitvami v Sloveniji dobilo nov zagon|access-date=2018-06-03|language=sl}} In August 2018, the party's publishing company, New Horizons, anonymously published the Slovene Identitarians' alt-right book, ''Manifesto for the Homeland''.{{Cite news|url=http://nova24tv.si/slovenija/jutri-izide-knjiga-za-katero-levicarji-grozijo-da-bi-jo-morali-prepovedali-prihaja-manifest-za-domovino/|title=[Video] Danes izide knjiga, za katero levičarji grozijo, da bi jo morali prepovedati; Prihaja Manifest za domovino! {{!}} Nova24TV|date=2018-08-28|work=Nova24TV|access-date=2018-09-05|language=sl-SI}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.mladina.si/187087/manifest-za-slovenijo-alpe-pa-francoske/|title=Manifest za Slovenijo, Alpe pa francoske {{!}} MLADINA.si|work=Mladina.si|access-date=2018-09-05}} The book was also promoted by SDS-affiliated media organisations and individuals, including SDS leader Janez Janša,{{Cite news|url=https://www.mladina.si/187087/manifest-za-slovenijo-alpe-pa-francoske/|title=Manifest za Slovenijo, Alpe pa francoske {{!}} MLADINA.si|work=Mladina.si|access-date=2018-09-09}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.mladina.si/187229/manifest-nove-desnice/|title=Manifest nove desnice {{!}} MLADINA.si|work=Mladina.si|access-date=2018-09-09}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.vecer.com/nova-obzorja-na-trg-s-knjigo-skupine-ki-siri-sovrazni-govor-6553758|title=Nova obzorja na trg s knjigo skupine, ki širi sovražni govor|work=Časnik Večer d.o.o.|access-date=2018-09-09|language=sl-si}} with SDS MP Žan Mahnič even going so far as to post on Twitter a photo of the book taken from his parliamentary seat, with the floor of the parliamentary chamber in the background. === Political self-dealing accusations === The party has been accused of political self-dealing and nepotism, appointing relatives, allies, and friends to government (and other) positions. Many close relatives of prominent SDS members have found employment in the Slovenian and European parliaments, high ranking public sector positions, and state-owned companies (some despite not meeting the official job requirements).{{Cite news|url=https://www.mladina.si/182937/nepotisticna-hobotnica/|title=Nepotistična hobotnica {{!}} MLADINA.si|work=Mladina.si|access-date=2018-06-05}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.mladina.si/120739/nepotizem/|title=Nepotizem {{!}} MLADINA.si|work=Mladina.si|access-date=2018-06-05}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.vecer.com/poleg-zana-janse-delata-za-tomcevo-tudi-petkov-sin-in-brat-jerajeve-6352314|title=Poleg Žana Janše delata za Tomčevo tudi Petkov sin in brat Jerajeve|work=Časnik Večer d.o.o.|access-date=2018-06-05|language=sl-si}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.mladina.si/49135/prvo-leto-kadrovanja/|title=Prvo leto kadrovanja {{!}} MLADINA.si|work=Mladina.si|access-date=2018-06-06}} SDS has been accused of political firings and replacements in, and selective financing of many institutions under the public sphere, and creating an environment where politisation of the public workplace was permissible and pervasive while in power.{{Cite news|url=https://www.mladina.si/185777/kaj-pomeni-jansa-na-oblasti/|title=Kaj pomeni Janša na oblasti? {{!}} MLADINA.si|work=Mladina.si|access-date=2018-06-06}} === Cult of personality === SDS leader Janez Janša has continuously served as party head since 1993 without a single other contender for the post. Party members are extremely loyal to Janša, and it has often been noted that the party appears to resemble a cult,{{Cite web|url=https://english.sta.si/2389847/delo-sees-sds-trapped-by-jansa-cult-and-past|title=STA: Delo sees SDS trapped by Janša cult and past|website=english.sta.si|language=en|access-date=2018-06-04}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.sloveniatimes.com/tough-driver-for-a-rocky-road|title=Tough Driver for a Rocky Road|website=www.sloveniatimes.com|language=sl|access-date=2018-06-04}} a view also shared by numerous past members of the party who claim any dissent within the party is strongly rebuked.{{Cite news|url=https://siol.net/novice/slovenija/poslanec-andrej-cus-zapusca-sds-417954|title=Andrej Čuš zapušča SDS in pravi: Nisem ne Janševa ne Kučanova lutka (video)|access-date=2018-06-05|language=sl}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.24ur.com/novice/slovenija/plaz-se-je-usul-andrej-cus-izstopil-iz-sds-vera-ban-ima-prav.html|title=Vsak dan prvi - 24ur.com|website=www.24ur.com|language=sl|access-date=2018-06-05}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.domovina.je/besede-s-katerimi-so-sds-zapuscali-njeni-ugledni-clani/|title=Besede, s katerimi SDS zapuščajo njeni ugledni člani {{!}} Domovina|last=Uredništvo|website=www.domovina.je|language=sl-SI|access-date=2018-06-05}}{{Cite news|url=https://novice.svet24.si/clanek/novice/slovenija/57e3c715973f2/iz-sds-odhaja-tudi-znidar|title=Janšo spet zapuščajo poslanci|work=Svet24.si|access-date=2018-06-05|language=sl-SI}} === Campaign financing impropriety allegations === In the run-up to the 2018 Slovenian parliamentary election, SDS attempted to receive a loan of €450.000 from an individual residing in [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]]{{Cite web|url=https://english.sta.si/2469274/report-sds-obtains-loan-from-individual-in-bosnia|title=STA: Report: SDS obtains loan from individual in Bosnia|website=english.sta.si|language=en|access-date=2018-06-03}} to fund its electoral campaign. The party came into contact with the individual via Nova obzorja publishing company (partially owned by SDS). SDS also put up its share in Nova obzorja as collateral.{{Cite web|url=https://www.24ur.com/novice/slovenija/nenavadno-posojilo-stranke-sds-od-32-letnice-iz-bih-najeli-kar-450-000-evrov-kredita.html|title=Vsak dan prvi - 24ur.com|website=www.24ur.com|language=sl|access-date=2018-06-05}} The sum borrowed exceeded limits set by campaign finance laws, however, and SDS was obliged to return the borrowed funds. A police and financial court investigation was also triggered after the terms of the loan became public.{{Cite news|url=https://siol.net/novice/slovenija/sds-vrnil-sporno-posojilo-z-obrestmi-457338|title=SDS vrnila sporno posojilo z obrestmi #video|access-date=2018-06-03|language=sl}} An investigation into the lender was also launched, based on suspicions of money laundering, tax avoidance, destruction and falsification of business documents, and overseeing dummy companies.{{Cite news|url=https://siol.net/posel-danes/novice/pranje-denarja-kaj-je-razkrila-parlamentarna-komisija-vzivo-467626|title=Pranje denarja: več kazenskih ovadb gre na policijo #video|access-date=2018-06-03|language=sl}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.24ur.com/novice/slovenija/dijana-dzudzic-naj-bi-z-razlicnih-racunov-dvignila-vec-kot-3-5-milijona-gotovine.html|title=Vsak dan prvi - 24ur.com|website=www.24ur.com|language=sl|access-date=2018-06-03}} The individual was allegedly a part of a criminal organisation managing dummy companies that received funds of undisclosed origins (including the funds later loaned to SDS).{{Cite news|url=http://www.delo.si/novice/slovenija/sds-si-je-denar-menda-izposodila-pri-muli-51788.html|title=SDS si je denar menda izposodila pri muli|last=Potič|first=Zoran|access-date=2018-06-03|language=sl-si}} Less than a week before the 2018 parliamentary election took place, it was revealed that media/publishing companies closely affiliated and partially owned by SDS received some €800.000 from two Hungarian nationals (or, rather, their companies) - both with close ties to Hungarian president [[Viktor Orbán]] - months before the election, bringing the total amount SDS-affiliated media companies received from Hungarian entities to over €2.2M. The SDS-affiliated media companies that received the funds in turn purchased campaign adds for SDS. Nova obzorja publishing company also attempted to loan €60,000 to the party. The same Hungarian individuals also provided funds for political allies in Makedonia. It is furthermore also known that the loan SDS attempted to obtain from a Bosnian citizen some months earlier had a Hungarian connection.{{Cite web|url=https://english.sta.si/2519419/foreign-campaign-financing-forbidden-sds-denies-bypass|title=STA: Foreign campaign financing forbidden, SDS denies bypass|website=english.sta.si|language=en|access-date=2018-06-03}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.vecer.com/volitve-schatz-in-adamikova-vbrizgala-svez-denar-v-medijski-sistem-sds-6482056|title=Svež denar v medijskem sistemu SDS: Kdo je Agnes Adamik?|work=Časnik Večer d.o.o.|access-date=2018-06-03|language=sl-si}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.mladina.si/185556/madzarski-dolznik/|title=Madžarski dolžnik {{!}} MLADINA.si|work=Mladina.si|access-date=2018-06-03}}{{Cite web|url=https://english.sta.si/2520180/alleged-hungarian-financing-of-sds-draws-ire-from-alde|title=STA: Alleged Hungarian financing of SDS draws ire from ALDE|website=english.sta.si|language=en|access-date=2018-06-03}} == Parliamentary representation == ImageSize = width:500 height:200 PlotArea = width:400 height:170 left:50
